text: to describe how inflation fits into the
BIGBANG picture that we've already
talked about a little bit I think the
key word is a word that comes from
Hollywood the word prequel inflation is
a prequel to the conventional Big Bang
picture there's inflation way on the
left top left cosmic inflation at about
10 to the minus 30 seconds it provides a
story that precedes the expansion of the
universe the formation of galaxies etc
etc and basically where it fills in is
an important point which Neil actually
mentioned the Big Bang Theory is a
misnomer what we call the Big Bang
Theory scientifically really says
nothing whatever about what banged why
it banged or what happened before it
banged the way in which inflation
explains the bang is in terms of a very
surprising feature of physics I think is
very surprising to most of us which is
the fact that gravity can actually
sometimes act impulsively now those of
us who learned about gravity in high
school and learned Newton's law of
gravity probably think this sounds crazy
because Newton's law of gravity is
purely an attractive law of gravity but
that got changed with the advent of
Einstein's theory of gravity which is
the theory called general relativity
according to general relativity gravity
normally acts attractively but there are
circumstances under which it can act
repulsively and furthermore modern
particle physics very strongly indicates
that at very high energies we expect
there to exist the kind of states of
matter that would produce the repulsive
form of gravity that general relativity
allows and inflation is basically the
proposal that the bang of the Big Bang
the driving force behind the expansion
was this repulsive gravity as allowed by
general relativity I should add that the
inflationary model depends heavily on
another very peculiar property of
physics a property that I think most of
us are are not used to which is the idea
that energies can be either positive or
negative and in fact the total energy of
our
universe is completely consistent with
adding up to zero zero in the form where
all the positive energies are in the
form of matter and radiation all the
stars and galaxies as you probably know
mass is really just a form of energy
according to relativity with the famous
e equals mc-squared
equivalence any mass is equivalent to an
energy which is the mass times C squared
all of those are positive contributions
to the energy the negative contribution
comes from the gravitational field that
fills the universe gravitational fields
actually have a negative contribution to
the total energy and as far as we can
tell the total energy the universe is
consistent with being exactly zero with
the cancellation these positive and
negative contributions and that's very
important especially to this idea of a
multiverse because it means that you can
produce universes for free
